qa_pairs.question: Explain the role of the inverse marginal cost (zi = φi/Wi) in the Shapiro–Stiglitz model's trade liberalization framework and how it affects firm entry decisions.
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The inverse marginal cost (zi = φi/Wi) in the Shapiro–Stiglitz model's trade liberalization framework serves as a performance indicator reflecting a firm's productivity (φi) relative to its wage (Wi). This measure is introduced to capture the relationship between firm-specific productivity and wages, which influences competitive dynamics in the market. In the context of trade liberalization, the inverse marginal cost affects firm entry decisions by determining the cutoff productivity level (z*) required for firms to enter the market. The Zero Cutoff Productivity (ZCP) condition and Free Entry (FE) condition, which depend on zi, establish the equilibrium threshold for entry. Firms with higher zi (indicating higher productivity relative to wages) are more likely to meet the profitability criteria for entry, while lower zi may deter entry due to reduced competitiveness.<cite>[S60]</cite></statement>

# Shapiro–Stiglitz theory



In labour economics, **Shapiro–Stiglitz theory** of efficiency wages (or **Shapiro–Stiglitz efficiency wage model**) is an economic theory of wages and unemployment in labour market equilibrium. [S2] It provides a technical description of why wages are unlikely to fall and how involuntary unemployment appears. [S3] This theory was first developed by Carl Shapiro and Joseph Stiglitz. [S4] ## Introduction

When full employment is achieved, if a worker is sacked, he automatically finds his next job soon. [S5] In the circumstances, he does not need to exert his effort in his job, and thus full employment necessarily motivates a worker to shirk provided that he is happy with loafing on the job. [S6] Since shirking makes a firm's productivity decline, the firm needs to offer its workers higher wages to eliminate shirking. [S7] Then all firms try to eliminate shirking, which pushes up average wages and decreases employment. [S8] Hence nominal wages tend to display downward rigidity. [S9] In equilibrium, all firms pay the same wage above market clearing, and unemployment makes job loss costly, and so unemployment serves as a worker-discipline device. [S10] A jobless person cannot convince an employer that he works at a wage lower than the equilibrium wage, because the owner worries that shirking occurs after he is hired. [S11] As a result, his unemployment becomes involuntary. [S12] ## No-shirking condition
